31cpBRWsShM.description: Dr.Zhuo is one of about 300 traditional Chinese medicine doctors in the Canadian province of British Columbia. A doctor in traditional medicine for 30 years, Zhuo has been running a clinic here in Vancouver since 2000. He says the number of patients has been growing and becoming more diverse in their backgrounds.
31cpBRWsShM.title: Traditional Chinese medicine doctor answers growing demand in Vancouver

G87SfHPHj0A.description:
UNESCO: Representative List of the Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity - 2010
URL: http://www.unesco.org/culture/ich/RL/00425
Description: Acupuncture and moxibustion are forms of traditional Chinese medicine widely practised in China and also found in regions of south-east Asia, Europe and the Americas. The theories of acupuncture and moxibustion hold that the human body acts as a small universe connected by channels, and that by physically stimulating these channels the practitioner can promote the human body's self-regulating functions and bring health to the patient. This stimulation involves the burning of moxa (mugwort) or the insertion of needles into points on these channels, with the aim to restore the body's balance and prevent and treat disease. In acupuncture, needles are selected according to the individual condition and used to puncture and stimulate the chosen points. Moxibustion is usually divided into direct and indirect moxibustion, in which either moxa cones are placed directly on points or moxa sticks are held and kept at some distance from the body surface to warm the chosen area. Moxa cones and sticks are made of dried mugwort leaves. Acupuncture and moxibustion are taught through verbal instruction and demonstration, transmitted through master-disciple relations or through members of a clan. Currently, acupuncture and moxibustion are also transmitted through formal academic education.
Country(ies): China
© 2009 Institute of Acupuncture and Moxibustion
Duration: 00:08:47 - Support: DVD (0042500018)
G87SfHPHj0A.title: Acupuncture and moxibustion of traditional Chinese medicine
G87SfHPHj0A.transcript: the techniques of acupuncture and moxibustion in traditional Chinese medicine are a traditional knowledge and practice formed in the soil of ancient Chinese culture for regulating the body's balance and maintaining health they are based on the holistic concept of unity between man and nature under the guidance of the theories of the channels and acupuncture points it's practice involves the insertion of needles into specific points on the body or the burning of moxa to warm the surface parts of the body in order to relieve pain treat illness or promote health the holistic concept of unity between man and nature which stems from ancient Chinese philosophy views the living individual as a component part of the universe and explains life activities with a theory of yin and yang for instance in the natural world yin represents the earth the moon and night whereas Jung represents the sky or heaven the Sun and day inside the human body upward movement represents yang whereas stability and downward movement represents in yin and yang govern nature as well as the body's interior therefore if the yin-yang balance between the external environment and the body or that within the body is upset disease results the theories of acupuncture and moxibustion hold that the human body is a microcosm each part of which is connected by channels through long-term practice points on the channels have been discovered gradually developing into a systematic theory of which the twelve channels correspond to the 12 months and 365 acupuncture points to the 365 days of the year this theory embodies the dynamic relationship between heaven man and earth for instance if a patient has a toothache on the left side it can be treated by inserting a needle in the Huggle point on the right hand the principle of selecting points on the lower body for diseases in the upper or of selecting points on the right for diseases on the left reflects clearly acupuncture and moxibustion a holistic view of the human body as an integral whole the practice of acupuncture and moxibustion can be explained as follows in acupuncture the primary tool is the needle historically needles were made of special stones or metals such as bronze iron gold and silver today needles are mostly made of stainless steel needles are selected according to the individual conditions and used to puncture and stimulate specific points to dredge the channels methods such as lifting thrusting twirling and rotating or comprehensive needle techniques are used for both prevention and treatment of disease nine needles of different shapes and dozens of different needle techniques were recorded in the classic of acupuncture in the second to third century BC the primary material used for moxibustion is Artemisia commonly known as the moxa plant which has a particular fragrance and grows in most parts of China since ancient times the Chinese have believed that it has the ability to dispel pathogenic factors toxic combs and sticks are made of moxa wool processed from moxa leaves which have been dried up and ground into wool moxa combs and moxa wool burn with an even warmth for a long period of time moxibustion is usually divided into direct and indirect forms in which either moxa combs are placed directly on points or moxa sticks are held and kept at some distance from the body service to warm the points so as to adjust the yin and yang of the body and restore balance and health acupuncture and moxibustion have been constantly reinvented in response to the environment and interactions with nature and history therefore characteristic regional group or individual schools have formed through endless exploration over the course of several millennia acupuncturists throughout history have improved upon the ancient art of acupuncture and moxibustion the three-step needle techniques improved upon by chen shannon are based on the relationships between heaven earth and man they summarize the three needle depths of superficial middle and deep the three free flow needle techniques summarized by her Parran are based on severity of illness and applies slight warming and strong promotion of free flow to treat disease these needle techniques have had far-reaching influences on promoting the continuing existence of this tradition in China to be a recognized master of the acupuncture tradition requires apprenticeship under a renowned acupuncturist acupuncture and moxibustion are primarily transmitted through example as well as verbal instruction through inherited lineages formed by master pupil relations all members of a clan these tradition bearers are identified by their reverence for the mythological figures of Quan D and to become an excellent reputable acupuncturist requires long-term accumulation of knowledge and practical experience the bronze figure of acupuncture points cast in 1026 in the Song Dynasty the systematic classic of acupuncture and moxibustion compiled in 259 and the great compendium of acupuncture and moxibustion written in 1601 as well as other works are all a testimony to the inheritance and development of this tradition and have served as important reference materials in the study of acupuncture and moxibustion and have been playing a significant role in their continued development up to the present day among the Chinese people there are sayings such as one needle and a bundle of herbs keeps you healthy into old age and hanging matzo leaves on your front door keeps the doctor away all year round these sayings are evidence that acupuncture and moxibustion have had a huge impact on people's lives and also reflect the widespread recognition of this ancient tradition acupuncture and moxibustion are a type of natural therapy which requires no medicine this comprehensive body of knowledge and steady rate of development have played an important role in promoting health care for the sake of protecting its continuous existence the China Association of acupuncture and moxibustion the institute of acupuncture and moxibustion of the china academy of chinese medical sciences and associated communities have launched wide-ranging movements for the study and practice of this tradition Chinese acupuncture and moxibustion is a living body of ancient Chinese wisdom and cultural legacy

GLtzOkEOQAU.description:
As seen on Innovations w/Ed Begley, Jr.

Traditional Chinese Veterinary Medicine (TCVM), although relatively new to the Western world, is a medical system that has been used in China to treat animals for thousands of years. It is an adaptation and extension of Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM) used to treat humans. In this segment, featured on Innovations Television, our producers traveled to the Chi Institute to educate viewers on traditional Chinese Medicine, and how it is being applied today into the veterinary world.
GLtzOkEOQAU.title: Traditional Chinese Veterinary Medicine

JAWLdQ3q5ug.description:
Marie Smurthwaite from Australia would like to explore the mystery of traditional Chinese medicine, TCM, as it has a history of 3000 years around. TCM follows the ancient Chinese principles of yin and yang. Over the gradual progression of these thousands of years, traditional Chinese medicine evolved to develop many forms of treatment, such as herbal medicine, acupuncture and moxibustion, tuina, massage, cupping, qigong, and food therapy.

Jqfz6bIgBpA.description: Researchers in China are working to standardize traditional Chinese medicine alongside Western styles.
Jqfz6bIgBpA.title: Researchers work to standardize traditional Chinese medicine

NmAOFMAZ6cI.description:
This is a rare glimpse into how a U.S.-trained cardiac surgeon and a team of clinicians trained in Integrative Medicine blend Western surgical techniques and Tradition Chinese Medicine to treat patients at the Guangdong Provincial Hospital of Chinese Medicine in Guangzhou, one of the most important Traditional Chinese Medicine hospital in China with over 12,000 out-patient visits each day.

About exploreIM.UCLA

As part of the UCLA Center for East West Medicine's ongoing effort to bridge the understanding of the integration of western medicine and Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM), it has launched Explore IM: Exploring Integrative Medicine, a web-based portal designed to be a world class interactive resource for integrative medicine.

Visit www.exploreim.ucla.edu
NmAOFMAZ6cI.title: Visiting a Traditional Chinese Medicine Hospital

QvEkkgnj9GM.description:
Traditional Chinese medicine (TCM) is a collection of a broad range of healing practices sharing common concepts that developed over thousands of years in what we know today as China. These practices evolved long before the development of science-based medicine. Although most people see TCM as complementary to orthodox medicine for those suffering relatively trivial problems, some market it toward those suffering from serious health conditions with the promise of helping with their symptoms or, in some cases, flat-out curing them. Although false hope peddling is commonplace here online, I wanted to see if the same opportunistic (almost predatory) approach to selling unproven medical products and services to the very ill is being practiced in the real world.

Support Myles through Patreon
http://patreon.com/powerm1985

MISTAKE!!!
I keep calling 3'-deoxyadenosine (Cordycepin) 3'-deoxyguanosine. Sorry - my brain was not working when I was recording.

S8VApNJwqSI.description: TCM therapist Britta Engert explains how diagnosis and therapy in traditional Chinese medicine differs from western medicine, the conditions that she treats and the effects of acupuncture on the body.
S8VApNJwqSI.title: How does traditional Chinese medicine work? | In Good Shape
S8VApNJwqSI.transcript: in good shape your health magazine on DW featuring an interview with a different expert every week when you go to a doctor he sometimes need to take your pulse like this year I'm a GP myself and I know that different kind of pulses that can be slow and they can be fast but if I go to a traditional Chinese medicine doctor he knows about 28 different kinds of pulses hi mrs. Inga thanks for inviting me into your clinic you're a traditional doctor for Chinese medicine right and where do you find those pulses on both sides on the right on the left hand side and usually you find them if you do if you apply your fingertips on each side and you take actually three fingers on each side and each position the left position has like a superficial pass and then you go a little bit deeper and then you have a deep pass so there are three levels of of pulses and that's what you do on both sides interesting with the 28 to pass the qualities you just talked about is that you really find different past qualities on each patient so some patients ever very long pass so long pass goes up to here for example or some patients have a very deep pass so you really have to press out in order to find any quality of the pulse and then you can also find like a very pulse we call it it's a very tight quality of pulses so what do you know after he took the pulse after after the after taking the pulse and the time usually in combination I can ask often questions to confirm what I feel and then I can have an idea where the problem lies of the patient so the digests a problem or it has other issues if you take a look at the background or the medicinal Chinese medicine there it's it's a complete different system then like we use here in Germany in the European version of medicine and what are the differences first of all the language is different so usually when I want to talk about the liver and living in a new system it's a complete different idea to what I know the liver for Chinese doctor is not the organ we know which sits in the upper right abdominal area thank you so usually for us it's it's a functional I never has a certain function so when the liver doesn't work properly or the flow of the liver doesn't work properly patients might feel headache quite often often in stressful situations or fears of pressure in any civil case there are different suitors to one organ where we can define where the problem lies and do you use those Western diagnostic systems like Hydra sound or MRI scan we do especially again this clinic we work in a hospital here so we have possibilities to actually ask our colleagues to check certain patients that we're not sure about and we would like to have the support of listeners so it's a very integrative method then yeah and and the other way around does it work the other way around that your colleagues from the Western medicine refer patients to you is it a Chinese doctor that works as well especially for colleagues that suffer from pain and a to have a quicker result because they need to work again so that's why we they come here and we occupant said another techniques so so pain is one thing and and what whether they are the main diagnosis or analysis you'd like to treat treat internal medicine from digestive problems sleeping disorders emotional disorders is long there's a vast variety possibilities for Chinese medicine acupuncture treatment is perhaps the most well known therapy in Chinese medicine where do you find all those points on the body it's easy to find on each patient because each patient has similar landmarks so like no matter what I treat a child or a grown-up you cannot just measure that by certain landmarks bones muscle and then it's easy to find those 365 points how many points you treat at the same session and it depends really from one to twenty different points it really depends on the patient the condition can you show us how you treated us so what I use is them I use them acupuncture needle which we use only once very thin stainless steel needles and then I use a guide tube which makes it much easier for the insertion for the patient because I keep anxious pain-free and so you can just that's all it's all so how do you feel sir almost nothing so it's not that painful and what happens in the body after you insert the needle the insertion of the needle just regulates implement inflammation processes and also the circulation that in Chinese medicine we call it the flow of Chi in of blood that we stimulate with the acupuncture so Chi is the energy which is flown through it energy exactly so you try to to relieve certain blockages of the body by using the needles but there's even a Western point of view when it comes to acupuncture that there's some hormones and neurotransmitters are secreted after you you press with Annie Laurie exactly there are lots of different scientific researches but that has been done on acupuncture and you can see that the changes of hormones and even the blood results um some of my patients bring new blood results their changes throughout the treatment as well it's quite interesting okay acupuncture is one side of Chinese medicine the other side is herbal treatments and so what you do with this kind of treatment Herbert treatment is also important in order to treat certain conditions so we combine acupuncture herbal medicine and herbal medicine they are usually we use a combination of herbs usually between five to twenty five thank if I would have for example and osteoarthritis degenerative bone disease and there is no traditional Chinese doctor in my vicinity so I have no chance to go to a traditional Chinese doctor but I want to use these herbs can I go into a pharmacy and treat myself usually you need a certain prescription which it's it's very important to get a correct diagnosis in order to get a good result so what we usually do we have lots of international patients that come to us for a consultation and then if they live away far away we usually they take to the herbs for one or two months home and then they come back to us I got a lot of questions concerning traditional Chinese medicine one from Qatar Halima al Kumari wants to know if you can treat cancer with means of TCM we have many patients that come with cancer and they use therapies like chemotherapy and what we can do we can support the treatment by giving vans herbs acupuncture to reduce the side effects of chemotherapy so you don't heal the cancer but you can lessen the side-effects of the traditional thanks so much for inviting me into your clinic today thank you and thank you so much for demonstrating the architecture with us thank you

SleTvTrbnYY.description: Dr. Maxine Barish-Wrenden of Sutter Medical Group, Sacramento talks about traditional eastern medicine such as accupuncture, to treat chronic conditions such as headaches.
SleTvTrbnYY.title: Alternative Medicine; Traditional Chinese Medicine
SleTvTrbnYY.transcript: let's talk about traditional Chinese medicine for a minute traditional Chinese medicine also known as TCM has been around for several thousand years it includes a number of different modalities including occup um sure massage Qi Gong and herbal medicine in contrast to Western medicine where we tend to focus on things like surgery and say antibiotics for infections or acute illness traditional chinese medicine tends to focus on prevention in fact some traditional Chinese doctors only got paid if their patients stayed well a big contrast in the u.s. how does it work well in traditional Chinese medicine it's felt that the body consists of a number of energy channels called meridians they run along the body and when that energy gets blocked in those meridians that's when illness is called to develop traditional Chinese medicine is often used for chronic symptoms let's take headaches for example Western doctors tend to treat headaches with medications but so have they stopped working in traditional Chinese medicine interventions like acupuncture and herbs can often be really helpful for chronic headaches in fact a recent study at Duke University showed that sixty-five percent of people getting occupied sure had an improvement in their headaches a great result I often refer my patients for traditional Chinese medicine especially when they're dealing with chronic symptoms that aren't getting better with Western therapies traditional Chinese medicine and other alternative therapies tend to focus on wellness and that's great

UBIEsmYLJrU.description:
Traditional Chinese medicine (TCM) is often met with skepticism by Westerners, but a TCM museum in Maryland is helping to educate Americans about the benefits.  

Subscribe to us on YouTube: https://goo.gl/lP12gA

Download our APP on Apple Store (iOS): https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/cctvnews-app/id922456579?l=zh&ls=1&mt=8

Weibo: http://weibo.com/cctvnewsbeijing
UBIEsmYLJrU.title: US museum spreads benefits of traditional Chinese medicine
UBIEsmYLJrU.transcript: at the 2016 Summer Olympics it wasn't just Michael Phelps's strokes that got all the attention it was the big purple marks all over his body the results of a traditional Chinese medicine technique known as cupping it involves using suction cups to stimulate circulation designed to treat pains and inflammation that helps sharpen the spotlight on Chinese medicine outside China it's the same mission here at the u.s. Center for Chinese medicine outside rockville maryland inside a 2,000 square meter museum said to be the first of its kind in the country it's headed by TCM professor dr. bolli san eeja gababa and loaded onto I'll show our exhibitions are four people from educational and research institutes medical centers and everyday people we let them know the history culture and advantages of the museum is designed for Western visitors who may have heard about Chinese medicine but don't know much about it one interactive exhibit allows visitors to sit down with a statue of a traditional doctor from decades past who didn't use fancy tools sama oval ASEAN countries considering John flora a traditional doctor in the clinic had a table a chair and a small pillow to test the pulps patients would sit here and let in testicles across the way you can look at pickup touch and smell plants and herbs used in TCM disposition my phone this is my dog to help relieve dry mouth dry mouth is a symptom of weak lungs so this is good for lung help this part is the most important different ones are combined to create a special mix to best treat the patient's condition a traditional pharmacist wooden cabinet stores and organizes the herbs in a specific order Chinese medicine is based on the concept that our body is an organic whole comprised of two parts the tangible body and the intangible spirit or cheap and all over our body are more than 300 a key points that correspond to all of our internal organs so they correspond to different parts of the body and point if it had different policies here under there it is that's the concept behind another TCM practice acupuncture inserting five needles into the body at specific points to treat illness it's practiced at a clinic next door to the museum the hope is that both facilities will take the mystery out of TCM and help convince skeptics who dismiss TCM as non scientific putting try looking in a lot of my patients who are using Western treatments use one to two large jars of painkillers every year they have a lot of pain and their headache comes back a lot acupuncture killed their headache eventually by adjusting their body environment they don't need pain killers anymore we hope our traditional Chinese medicine can spread all over the world so more people can benefit from it Frances Cosi GTN Rockville Maryland

iQJFp5UIaOY.description:
Charmian is the Head of Chinese Medicine Department and a Senior Lecturer in the School of Health and Bioscience at The University of East London. In her talk she talks about her 20 years' experience in learning about and practising acupuncture in the UK and Nanjing, China. What is it about those little needles that make them alleviate pain, treat illnesses and even help women to get pregnant?

What is TEDx?

In the spirit of ideas worth spreading, TED has created a program called TEDx. TEDx is a program of local, self-organized events that bring people together to share a TED-like experience. Our event is called TEDxBratislava, where x = independently organized TED event. At our TEDxBratislava event, TEDTalks video and live speakers will combine to spark deep discussion and connection in a small group. The TED Conference provides general guidance for the TEDx program, but individual TEDx events, including ours, are self-organized.
iQJFp5UIaOY.title: TEDxBratislava - Charmian Wylde - The wonder of Chinese medicine
iQJFp5UIaOY.transcript: Translator: salma farag Checker: Riyad Almubarak  Hello all.  Thank you very much for inviting me to Bratislava.  You know, it's a funny story.  You go back and forward to Vienna  And use the London-Bratislava line,  The trips took almost a week after another.  A very nice woman sat beside me  For what I told her it was my last trip to Bratislava.  And I said that with a little rest  Because, you know, flying is often very tiring.  And anyway, as the journey progresses -  We have two hours from London to Bratislava -  She said, "Well, what are you doing?"  I told her that I had been involved in Chinese medicine for 20 years.  So we talked, and you inked me,  Well, what do you think to return to Bratislava  And talk at TED about your experience? "  So, you know, never make it hard; I'm here again,  Because, in fact, you have a beautiful city here  With a wonderful castle.  So, I'm grateful to be here, thank you.  (clap)  Anyway, I have rather an unusual job.  I, in the mid-1980s,  I decided instead to change my life and study Chinese medicine,  Which not many people in London are doing these days.  I've been able to learn Chinese medicine in London,  And I thought, "Wonderful, what a wonderful system of medicine."  It comes from China.  About 3,000 years old,  It operates based on a completely different basis than Western medicine.  But there was little of me that was cynical  And I thought, "Well, how does it work?"  Because what happens here is that we are inserting needles into people's bodies  At different acupuncture points,  And suddenly they get better.  There is no scientific explanation  Of how this medical system actually works.  So I thought, "It's time to go to China."  So in 1991, I went to China, to Nanjing,  I lived and worked in a busy traditional medicine hospital.  And this really changed my life,  Partly, you know, there was no small private room.  There was no, you know, comfortable, intimate conversation  About what happened when we were five or six years old or so,  And made us sick, perhaps, today.  You know, this was a system  Where hundreds and hundreds of people were coming to this busy hospital,  They were getting better.  What I saw was that things were very similar to shingles,  Very painful explosions on the body,  But surrounded by acupuncture needles gone within two or three days.  Things like facial paralysis, you know,  Very physical symptoms where half of the face is frozen,  And people are getting better.  So I had no doubt in my mind that Chinese medicine had something.  So I went back to the UK;  I went to practice, to set up my own clinic with colleagues,  And really, to some extent, it was a great experience in Britain.  We didn't really know what could be cured.  But people keep coming to us, and people are getting better.  And then it's hard to believe when I started all this,  Teaching acupuncture go to universities,  And to cut a long story short,  I find myself at the University of East London.  I'm the head of Chinese medicine there.  And I'm so happy to tell you,  I have one student from Bratislava that I hope will pass her exams this year.  So you will bring Chinese medicine back here.  So here we are, for me 20 years old I do it,  To date there is no scientific explanation of how this drug works.  And I want to tell you a short story about a patient  Let's give you some ideas about what acupuncture involves.  Let's call it Nadine.  She is thirty years old,  She and her husband  For two years trying to have a baby,  But it can not afford.  She goes for tests to her doctor, and tests reveal no problem:  "You should be able to conceive."  So they continue to despair,  It has two courses of the so-called IVF, the concept of assistance,  They don't work.  So as a last resort, they come to me for acupuncture treatment.  And to be honest, you know, this is a big task,  You know, to give this woman a child, with needles.  (Laughter)  No, there is no play here.  So, anyway,  We diagnose and listen to her pulse.  I do all the things that Chinese doctors do,  We've been working together for five months,  And nothing happens - she does not carry.  And I started feeling uncomfortable  Because they pay money for treatment,  And one day I told her,  "Look, I'm not sure this acupuncture is yours."  She looked at me and said,  "You are like my mother:  You think I'm useless. You think I can't do this. "  And you know, she was flowing out of anger,  And I said, "You mean your mother doesn't think you can conceive?"  "No," she said.  She said, "I'm so angry."  Now, in Chinese medicine,  Chinese has long been recognized  There is a connection between mind and physical function.  So on this particular occasion, I changed the acupuncture treatment.  And when I put the needles in,  There was a little electric shock that seemed different,  And this taking into account we've been working together five months.  And imagine what? I have loaded.  You know, there are many stories like this.  That's why, you know, the Chinese kept Chinese medicine.  And just, because I don't know how many people are here  Know what really be Chinese medicine,  But acupuncture is one remedy,  Herbal remedies, massage and movement are also available.  For example, in China, I visited Cancer Hospital,  They don't put their people down when they have cancer.  Keep them moving with things like qigong and taiji -  It's a different philosophy, a different way of thinking.  As you know, in China this drug has been used for 3000 years.  The idea is that the body is a network of meridians, or channels,  These channels seem to carry something called chi.  Now, there is no definition for Che.  There is no explanation you cannot measure.  There is no science explaining what Che is.  This of course makes people in the scientific establishment  Very very skeptical about what we do.  In China, there is no energy. It's not some primitive life force.  In fact, it gives meaning to things.  This conference today has a good chi.  You know, she has tremendous energy behind her.  Really gives purpose and meaning;  Creates life - this is the idea of ​​Che.  Chinese medicine is really a system of clinical evidence  Based on a very different way of thinking about the body.  So, for example,  Emotions, in Chinese medicine, can cause disease.  So, as with the patient I told you about,  The idea that all this suppressed anger,  In fact, in Chinese medicine will have some convenience.  So Chinese medicine is a great success story.  I visited Cuba in my work  Because I heard it in Cuba  Chinese medicine was part of their integrated health care system.  And you know, when Cuba was isolated from the rest of the world  And they have no essential drugs,  They had to experience acupuncture.  They find it successful for things like strokes and heart attacks,  Now in Cuba today, you'll find two medical systems:  You'll find traditional medicine as well as contemporary Western medicine.  And I said in Cuba, to the president of the Cuban Acupuncture Association,  "Why? Why acupuncture here?"  He said, "Because Chinese medicine is one of the best systems in the world,  One of the best medical systems,  We want one of the best medical systems for the Cuban people. "  So, in Britain, you know, acupuncture is very popular.  But we, in the last two years,  You experience great hostility from the scientific establishment.  "Where is your guide?" They say.  "You should just have a placebo" You know, the idea of ​​the proposal.  Well, maybe, because placebo works in many medical systems,  But I think it's more.  I'm absolutely convinced that when you enter those needles,  Something going on.  We know some things now.  We know that acupuncture affects the limbic part of the brain.  We also know in the treatment of infertility  That's in the middle of the month if you acupuncture,  Increases blood flow to the uterus.  So we started to understand.  But at the same time, with all the hostility -  She is serious in Britain.  I mean, for example, there are people within the scientific establishment  Who want to close university courses like mine.  There are many books published saying, "What is happening in Britain?  People suddenly start to believe in things that are irrational. "  So, you know, these people ask good questions,  Because I particularly, as a teacher, have to ask myself, you know:  Well, did something happen here?  Or this is the medicine system, which is 3,000 years old,  Is it a good idea  Or something depends on, you know, on almost magic?  But I think Chinese medicine has two things  This western medicine does not have it.  The first is that Chinese medicine is a true art.  No practitioner needs to listen and consider.  They listen to the pulse. They listen to the patient's life -  The disease is not just an isolated group of symptoms.  It is our way of life, our history and what we want to do  Effect and can actually cause poor health.  It's a really innovative process almost an art form.  And know from art, only with the music that we heard before,  How this can actually create change makes us think differently.  The second thing for me about Chinese medicine,  Something really came across in China -  And you know what we did in the West  You made it very hierarchical, every important system of medicine  With language patients often do not understand.  It's often scary for patients. It is often gaseous.  But, you know, in China, a doctor told me,  "You know, Charmian,  Here is actually a patient that is God and not a doctor. "  And I found this over and over again,  This Chinese medicine tends to empower people;  Enable them to take much greater responsibility for their health,  I think this is what they offer.  So I just want to finish I'd like to show you a clip.  I prepared to visit China just before Christmas this year,  I was taken to a hospital in Shenyang, in northern China,  There is a doctor there  Who developed a technique to treat low back pain,  I would leave you with a quick clip.  It looks very exciting.  This is a very traditional treatment.  It's for lower back pain and sciatica.  Look over,  Even if you're in trouble,  I hope in Bratislava you will have a choice of having acupuncture.  (Video) Female voice: [this drug] originated from the northeastern part of China  Charmian: What kind of conditions? Only pain? Back pain in general?  Female: Yes Yes Yes.  Man: Wrinkles and shocks.  Man: You can see the fire along the channel.  Charmian: Yes, I can see it. It's wonderful.  Man: It's hot. Just feel it.  You can repeat the fire.  Female: And medicine can also be very good.

uHpeTBUBv5k.description:
The Colorado School of Traditional Chinese Medicine, nestled at the foot of the majestic Rocky Mountains in Denver’s historic Capitol Hill neighborhood, is proud to offer 2 nationally accredited Master of Science programs. 

The 2,265 hour, 28 month accelerated, M.S.in Acupuncture degree and the 2,850 hour, 3 year accelerated M.S. in TCM degree.

Our unique program blends the ancient wisdoms of Chinese Medicine, including tai chi and qi gong, acupuncture, Tuina massage, Gua Sha, moxibustion, fire cupping, electro-stimulation, and Chinese herbal
medicine with a solid foundation in western biomedical sciences, nutrition, and business management.

Our video offers words and testimonials from faculty, staff and students who describe the experience, reputation and successes of the Colorado School of Traditional Chinese Medicine.   

You will be introduced to many areas and aspects of the school, including the Student Clinic, Classrooms, Faculty, Staff and Teachers, as well as our Herbal Pharmacy.  

Learn more:

http://www.cstcm.edu

Music by
Kevin MacLeod (incompetech.com)
Licensed under Creative Commons: By Attribution 3.0
http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/
uHpeTBUBv5k.title: Colorado School of Traditional Chinese Medicine - Video Overview

information needs of faculty students and patients in addition the library and classrooms offer high-speed wireless internet access SIA is amazing because some even just one needle and even just use some look or find some herb and can quickly review the symptom so he's amazing we care about every one of our students their success in school and their TCM practice to follow in addition to our clinic library and herbal store our facilities offer large open classrooms a student lounge and house a variety of resident practitioners the Massage Therapy Institute of Colorado and the luxurious ease bus spa I think the best attribute actually is the commitment the school and the founders of the school have had to to the medicine since they started and it's indoor like it's the school's new it was 25 years old and that commitment to the medicine and producing quality highly trained practitioners as the glass their commitment is really shows I think it's the best attribute yeah because of the commitment to the medicine the school has always had a strong bull program which I think it could be commended for and I know now that students have an option to do the acupuncture on me degree and then finish the TCM degree after they've got out and start practising acupuncture which i think is a benefit because they can get out and start seeing patients start actually working in the field and then come in and finish off the herbal training and be a stronger practitioner for us to break away and enjoy Colorado's glorious weather students often utilize our rooftop deck as they relax study and practice community in Tai Chi and Qigong and just footsteps or a bike ride away students will find a variety of restaurants shops art galleries several city parks several museums the Denver Botanic Gardens and the Denver Zoo Denver has ample employment and housing opportunities and offers a unique combination of city culture within close proximity to abundant nature well certainly Denver is one of the most diverse cities in the nation very integrated lots of different people lots of opportunity here the city is growing and CBS TCM is like right in the heart of this new Denver that has been emerging over the last I'd say decade since its foundation in 1989 our administration have remained committed to making this extensive TCM program accessible to any student truly devoted to learning the art of healing we are more affordable than comparable programs around the country while offering as much or even more advanced training CST cm works hard to offer supportive educational atmosphere we make every effort to assist students in obtaining educational funding we are certified by the US Department of Education to participate in the title for student aid programs including Stafford grad plus and alternative student loans additionally we are approved for various Colorado State vocational rehabilitation programs and Veterans Affairs Rehabilitation and educational benefits and as apposed 9/11 GI Bill we accept new students three times per year trimesters begin in January early May and late August students may enroll with as few as 60 college credits we have either day or evening classes to choose from but I think that this medicine is inherently self loving and you know you really are taught to take care of yourself as well as others so I really just try to apply the medicine to myself as much as possible and yes sleep and eat good foods and you know rest when I can and just find time to do peaceful things so that my brain can take a break but our program is not for everyone it will challenge you not only to become a great healer but indeed a greater person our graduates are in their respect through hard work dedication professionalism and continuous personal growth when we finally give a graduate their diploma per se in the community now as we do that they are not simply trained in Chinese medicine but are in fact a true healer capable of making a real difference in today's world yeah excellent teachers I really appreciate the variety and very the varying styles of the different practitioners that come from different areas of the tradition I think that is enriched the experience significantly because we're getting so many different points of view sometimes it's a lot to take in but once you digest it we can approach it from so many different angles I think that that's great with the faculty also and with the clinic I just started the clinic this semester it's been a great I've been paired with a great team and they're very helpful and enabling me and the other students that are on my same level to move forward and to grow and apply what you know what we've learned our school brings together unique diversity of students faculty and staff devoted to living and promoting healthier holistic lifestyles it's a community full of life art and culture join us at our annual Chinese New Year celebration one of our summer barbecues or bowling parties and you'll see just how special and beautiful this is in the words of Lao Tzu the journey of a thousand miles begins with the first step and we invite you to take the first step here at a Colorado School of traditional Chinese medicine for more information explore our website at WWDC meed you from there you can download our catalog and application if you have specific questions would like to arrange a tour or observe one of our classes please call us at 3 0 3 3 2 9 6 3 5 5

yOtodp2veKQ.description:
Hi Beauties! I talked about acne in several of my videos already, and tried to suggest a few different solutions to treat it. This time, I will explain why you have acne from a traditional Chinese medicine point of view and based on ancient Chinese principles and beliefs. Back in the ancient times, Chinese people didn't have today's technology to treat their acne, but their natural treatments were nonetheless effective.

☞ More Videos: http://bit.ly/10QKLHI 
☞ Check out all deals from Ebates here : http://bit.ly/2bo4n72
☞ Get 10% off with promo code ABSMIA on Sigma Brushes through this link: http://bit.ly/1Zfi8Tp

Don't forget to ask questions, write, or just say hi to me on:
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/ABSNTDTV
Instagram: ABSNTDTV
Twitter: ABSNTDTV
Snapchat: ABSNTDTV

Some secrets are better shared than kept, thank you for watching ^_~ asian beauty secrets
